name: Baltimore Metro SubwayLink
overview: The Metro SubwayLink is a heavy rail rapid transit line operated by the Maryland Transit Administration serving the Baltimore metropolitan area. Running 15.4 miles from Owings Mills in Baltimore County through downtown Baltimore to Johns Hopkins Hospital in East Baltimore, it is the only rapid transit line in Maryland. The system features both surface and deep-bore tunnel sections, with six underground stations in the downtown core.

history.title: Major Construction Begins
history.description: Full-scale construction begins on Section A, the initial 7.6-mile segment from Charles Center to Reisterstown Plaza.

history.title: System Opens
history.description: First 7.6-mile, 8-station segment from Charles Center to Reisterstown Plaza opens to passengers with 72 Budd UTV cars. Total construction cost was approximately $1.4 billion.

history.title: Owings Mills Extension Opens
history.description: 6.1-mile western extension from Reisterstown Plaza to Owings Mills opens with 3 new stations: Old Court, Milford Mill, and Owings Mills.

history.title: Johns Hopkins Extension Opens
history.description: Final 1.6-mile eastern extension opens with 2 new stations, Shot Tower and Johns Hopkins Hospital, completing the 14-station, 15.4-mile line.

history.title: Fleet Refurbishment Begins
history.description: All 100 Budd UTV cars undergo midlife refurbishment including seat reupholstery, floor replacement, and LED destination displays.

history.title: System Rebranded as SubwayLink
history.description: MTA Maryland rebrands all services under the unified 'Link' family. The Metro Subway becomes 'Metro SubwayLink' alongside CityLink buses and Light RailLink.

history.title: New Railcar Contract Awarded
history.description: MTA awards $400.5 million contract to Hitachi Rail for 78 new metro cars and Communications-Based Train Control (CBTC) signaling, the first fleet replacement in system history.

history.title: Hitachi Rail Cars Enter Service
history.description: New Hitachi Rail metro cars enter revenue service, marking the first fleet replacement in the system's 42-year history. The new cars feature AC propulsion, digital signage, and improved accessibility.
